{{coord|44.110119|N|27.270892|E|type:landmark_region:BG|display=title}} [[File:Roman Tomb Silistra TB.JPG|thumb|Exterior view of the Roman Tomb of Silistra]] The '''Roman Tomb of Silistra''' ({{lang-bg|Римска гробница в Силистра}}, ''Rimska grobnitsa v Silistra'') is an [[Roman funerary practices|Ancient Roman burial tomb]] in the town of [[Silistra]] in northeastern [[Bulgaria]]. Dating to the mid-4th century AD, the Roman Tomb is the best-preserved architectural monument of the [[Roman Empire|Ancient Roman]] city of Durostorum. The tomb is considered "one of the most investigated and most discussed monuments of the late antique art in Bulgaria" and the [[Balkans]],<ref name="atanasov447">Atanasov, p. 447.</ref> owing in large part to the quality and extent of its interior frescoes.
==History== Though the influence of Christianity had reached Silistra by the time, the Roman Tomb is clearly an example of pagan art commissioned by a pagan owner. Thus, it is considered likely that it predates [[Theodosius I]]'s persecution of [[Roman paganism]]. Its construction also likely preceded the [[Goths|Gothic]] invasion of Durostorum of 376–378, which caused great turmoil in the city. The invasion may have caused the master's family depicted in the tomb to flee the city, explaining the lack of burials in the tomb.<ref>Atanasov, p. 451.</ref> In any case, the tomb must be stylistically ascribed to the 4th century and specifically to Theodosius I's reign.<ref name="henning">{{cite book|last=Henning|first=Joachim|title=Post-Roman Towns, Trade and Settlement in Europe and Byzantium: Byzantium, Pliska, and the Balkans|publisher=Walter de Gruyter|date=2007|isbn=3110183579|pages=84–85}}</ref>
The Roman Tomb was coincidentally discovered in 1942 in the southern outskirts of Silistra, a major town in [[Southern Dobruja]] on the banks of the Lower [[Danube]]. Silistra had only recently been transferred by [[Romania]] back to Bulgaria as part of the 1940 [[Treaty of Craiova]]. Since 1984, the Roman Tomb of Silistra has been on [[UNESCO]]'s Tentative List of [[World Heritage Site]]s.<ref name="unesco">{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/48/|title=The late ancient tomb of Silistra|publisher=UNESCO|accessdate=23 January 2016}}</ref>
==Architecture and frescoes== [[File:Roman Tomb Silistra fresco servant.jpg|thumb|A fresco portraying a female servant carrying gifts to the master's family]] The stone tomb features a single [[burial chamber]] and measures {{convert|3.30|by|2.60|m|ft|abbr=off|lk=on}}. It has a west-east orientation, with the entrance on the east wall and a semi-cylindrical brick vault.<ref name="atanasov448">Atanasov, p. 448.</ref> It is located amidst the ruins of a [[necropolis]] from [[Late Antiquity]] which included other similar structures.<ref name="henning"/>
Ceramic plates, rectangular in shape and painted using the [[fresco-secco]] technique, cover the entirety of its floor. In contrast to most other known Roman tombs from the period in the Balkans, the entire interior is covered by multi-coloured mural paintings. The northern, southern and eastern walls feature a procession of [[Slavery in ancient Rome|servants]],<ref name="atanasov448"/> whereas the frescoes of the western wall, directly opposite the entrances, depict the master and his wife.<ref>Atanasov, p. 449.</ref>
A [[frieze]] running along the walls of the tomb contains 11 panels featuring the portraits of male and female slaves bringing various gifts and garments to the masters.<ref name="henning"/><ref name="unesco"/> The procession runs from either side of the central panel that portrays the masters, providing for a symmetrical composition. The tomb's decoration also includes hunting scenes, candlesticks, plants and animals, including [[peacock]]s and [[pigeon]]s.<ref name="henning"/> Overall, the decoration's remarkable level of preservation and the quality of the mural paintings makes the tomb a "unique example of art and life" in the outer regions of the Roman Empire during the turbulent 4th century.<ref name="unesco"/>
The Roman Tomb of Silistra is situated at the intersection of the Sedmi Septemvri and Boyka Voyvoda Streets in the town. As of 2016, it can only be toured after a prior reservation at the Regional Historical Museum of Silistra.<ref name="rim-silistra">{{cite web|url=http://museumsilistra.com/index.php/2-uncategorised/49-rimska-grobnitza|title=Римска гробница|publisher=Регионален исторически музей|language=Bulgarian|accessdate=23 January 2016}}</ref>

{{italic title}} '''''Rustic Wedding Symphony''''', Op. 26 (''Ländliche Hochzeit'') is a symphony in [[E-flat major|E flat major]] by [[Karl Goldmark]], written in 1875,<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=AF0m0117DIwC&pg=PA240&lpg=PA240&dq=rustic+wedding+symphony&source=web&ots=3jnmB7ur5n&sig=KkU4AZX-M85ZW325bQkFkbujzRg&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=3&ct=result David Ewen: Music for the Millions – The Encyclopedia of Musical Masterpieces]</ref> a year before his renowned [[Violin Concerto No. 1 (Goldmark)|Violin Concerto No. 1]]. The symphony was premiered in [[Vienna]] on 5 March 1876, conducted by [[Hans Richter (conductor)|Hans Richter]].<ref>[http://encyclopedia.farlex.com/Rustic+Wedding The Free Dictionary]</ref> [[Johannes Brahms]], who was a frequent walking companion of Goldmark's, and whose own [[Symphony No. 1 (Brahms)|Symphony No. 1]] was not premiered until November 1876, told him "That is the best thing you have done; clear-cut and faultless, it sprang into being a finished thing, like Minerva from the head of Jupiter".<ref name=braunstein>Joseph Braunstein, notes to Abravanel recording</ref> Its first American performance was at a New York Philharmonic Society concert, conducted by [[Theodore Thomas (conductor)|Theodore Thomas]] on 13 January 1877.<ref name=braunstein/>
The work does not conform to the standard structure of a symphony, and it could just be named a Suite. It is in five movements rather than the usual four, which is same as [[Ludwig van Beethoven|Beethoven]]'s [[Symphony No. 6 (Beethoven)|''Pastoral Symphony'']], [[Hector Berlioz|Berlioz]]'s ''[[Symphonie fantastique]]'' and [[Robert Schumann|Schumann]]'s [[Symphony No. 3 (Schumann)|''Rhenish Symphony'']].<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=1093WaBF3p4C&pg=PA29&lpg=PA29&dq=rustic+wedding+symphony&source=web&ots=PrYutZIOts&sig=mzgn8HLDZKo-YyCN0gYctRNdGQk&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=5&ct=result Michael Talbot, The Finale in Western Instrumental Music]</ref> It is full of Central European charm, joviality and good humour. While Goldmark did not provide any specific program for the work, he did give each of the movements titles suggestive of aspects of a wedding in the countryside.
The first movement is a Wedding March (''Hochzeitsmarsch'') followed by a set of 13 variations. While variations are commonly found in symphonies, it is most unusual for them to appear in the first movement. The variations offer constant changes of tempo, meter, rhythm, mood and harmony, and display his fine craftsmanship.<ref name=braunstein/> * The theme of the March is reminiscent of ''[[Adeste Fideles]]'', and is stated by cellos and basses in octaves. * Variation 1 is played in horns, clarinets and flutes * Variation 2, ''Poco animato'', introduces the violins * Variation 3, full orchestra * Variation 4, ''Andante con moto'', B flat minor, the theme played by the violins * Variation 5, ''Allegretto'', basses, bassoons and horns * Variation 6, ''Allegro vivace'', horns, bassoons, flutes and violins * Variation 7 involves part writing, again in a minor key * Variation 8, ''Allegro scherzando'', strings, flutes, oboes and clarinets * Variation 9, minor key, basses, violins and flutes * Variation 10, ''Molto vivace'', violins with other strings pizzicato * Variation 11, ''Andante con moto'', violins, oboe and clarinet * Variation 12, ''Moderato'', a new melody based on the original theme, oboe, bassoon, viola and two violins * Variation 13, after a brief fanfare, the original theme is played in the original tempo, but with the full orchestra, and then ends quietly.<ref name=faulkner>[https://books.google.com/books?id=-XWDqySOhrAC&pg=PA474&lpg=PA474&dq=rustic+wedding+symphony&source=web&ots=C5HFIVMSKa&sig=9gszQG8CVJ0VKd_RVCS4U9NbFuI&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=1&ct=result#PPA475,M1 Anne Shaw Faulkner, What We Hear in Music]</ref>
The second movement is a Bridal Song (''Brautlied''). The third movement, ''Serenade'', opens with a theme played by two oboes, later developed by the strings.<ref name=faulkner/> It includes an imitation of bagpipes, played on oboe, clarinet, bassoon and cellos.
The fourth movement, In the Garden (''Im Garten''), is slow and lyrical, its middle section moving to E-flat minor. The finale, ''Dance'', is the only movement of the work written in [[sonata form]]. It opens with a fugue.<ref>[http://www.buywell.com/booklets/4768743.pdf Raymond Tuttle, Notes to Decca recording]</ref> The Garden theme briefly reappears, before the Dance returns to end the movement rousingly.
The ''Rustic Wedding Symphony'' was a favourite of conductors such as [[Thomas Beecham]]<ref>[http://www.classicalsource.com/db_control/db_concert_review.php?id=4252 classical.source.com]</ref> and [[Leonard Bernstein]].<ref>[http://www.smh.com.au/news/arts/sydney-symphony/2008/03/16/1205602189219.html Harriet Cunningham, review of Sydney Symphony performance, Sydney Morning Herald, 17 March 2008]</ref> It has been recorded a number of times, by conductors such as Beecham, Bernstein, [[André Previn]], [[Maurice Abravanel]], [[Jesús López-Cobos]], [[Yondani Butt]] and [[Stephen Gunzenhauser]].

{{Infobox Artwork | image_file=Zampieri St John Evangelist.jpg | title=Saint John the Evangelist | artist=[[Domenico Zampieri|Domenico Zampieri (Domenichino)]] | year=1621–1629? | medium=[[Oil on canvas]] | height_metric=259 | width_metric=199.4 | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in }}
'''''Saint John the Evangelist''''' is a painting by the Italian Baroque painter [[Domenico Zampieri|Domenichino]]. In February 2014 it was on display in the [[National Gallery, London]], on loan from a private collection.
==History== The painting is thought to have been commissioned by either [[Benedetto Giustiniani|Benedetto]] (1554–1621) or his brother [[Vincenzo Giustiniani]] (1564–1637) since it appears in the 1638 [[Giustiniani]] inventory. Paintings of Saints [[Saint Matthew|Matthew]], [[Saint Mark|Mark]] and [[Saint Luke|Luke]] (by [[Nicolas Régnier]], [[Francesco Albani]] and [[Guido Reni]] respectively) are also included, all stated to be the same size as the Saint John. It has been suggested therefore that the four paintings were originally intended as a series.<ref name="christies"/>
Despite the prestigious commission, the date of the painting's execution remains unclear. Richard E. Spear, author of numerous publications on [[Seicento|17th-century Italian painting]] and one of the foremost scholars on the life and work of Domenichino,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oberlin.edu/faculty/rspear/spear.html|title=Richard E. Spear|publisher=|accessdate=19 June 2015}}</ref> put the work at around 1627 to 1629. This is due to stylistic similarities with works such as the Sant'Andrea della Valle's ''Saint John''. An alternative theory, put forward in Squarzina's analysis of the 1938 Giustiniani inventory, speculates that the work could be from before 1621. Others have concluded dates between 1624 and 1628.
The painting descended via Vincenzo Giustiniani's heir to Prince Benedetto Giustiniani, in whose posthumous inventory of 1793 it appears, then to Andrea Giustiniani, who in 1804 declined a purchase offer of 6,500 [[scudo (Italian coin)|scudi]] for it. Andrea then had it taken to Paris, probably before 1806, where he sold it to [[Alexis Delahante]]. Delahante and W. Harris then sold it to Richard Hart Davis and it was then sold in around 1813 with the rest of Davis's collection to Philip John Miles. Inherited firstly by his son, [[Sir William Miles, 1st Baronet|William Miles]] then his grandson [[Sir Philip John William Miles, 2nd Baronet|Philip Miles]], the picture was kept at [[Leigh Court]] where it, along with others in the family's extensive collection, could be viewed upon application. The impact of the [[Long Depression]] and an agricultural crisis depressing farm prices due to cheap imports from abroad, however, simultaneously attacked this landowning and banking family's sources of income and caused Sir Philip to seek to sell in 1884 at [[Christie's]] where part of the collection was among the first to be sold under the terms of Gladstone's [[Settled Lands Act]]. However, Domenichino and his contemporaries had by then gone out of fashion with British buyers and the ''Saint John the Evangelist'' remained unsold.
It was then auctioned at Christie's again in 1899 on the death of Cecil Miles, 3rd Baronet who was Philip John Miles's great-grandson – this time it was bought in at 100 guineas and subsequently sold for 70 guineas to M. Colnaghi, acting as agent for Augustus Langham Christie of Tapeley Park, Devonshire and Glyndebourne, East Sussex, part of the Christie family. The painting passed down through that family (later headed by [[John Christie (opera manager)|John Christie]] and known for their connection to the [[Glyndebourne Festival Opera]]) for more than a century until it was auctioned in London in December 2009 to an American buyer for £9.2 million. However, it was then the object of an [[export bar]] to keep it in the [[United Kingdom]] due to its history of ownership in the country. British galleries were unable to raise enough money to buy it (the [[National Gallery, London|National Gallery]] and [[National Galleries of Scotland]] already being committed to an expensive deal to buy ''[[Diana and Actaeon (Titian)|Diana and Actaeon]]'' and ''[[Diana and Callisto]]'', both by [[Titian]]), but another anonymous collector was allowed to acquire it on the condition that it be displayed to the public for three months each year. He then loaned it to the National Gallery in London from May 2010 to August 2011, where it had previously been displayed from 1992 to 1994.<ref>[https://archive.is/20120917155603/http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard/article-23741650-details/Glyndebourne+family+to+sell+Old+Master+for+10+million/article.do Glyndebourne family to sell Old Master for £10 million], ''London Evening Standard'', 9 Sept 2009</ref><ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2010/may/18/saved-painting-domenichino-national-gallery 'Saved' Domenichino painting loaned to National Gallery], Guardian, 18 May 2010</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment_and_arts/10119883.stm|title=Baroque painting by master Domenichino saved for nation|work=BBC News|accessdate=19 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/art/news/private-collectors-16392m-saves-masterpiece-from-export-1975587.html|title=Private collector's £9.2m saves masterpiece from export - News - Art - The Independent|work=The Independent|accessdate=19 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.artdaily.org/index.asp?int_sec=11&int_new=33182|title=Domenichino Masterpiece to Be Offered at Christie's Auction of Old Masters and 19th Century Art|author=Ignacio Villarreal|publisher=|accessdate=19 June 2015}}</ref>
==Description== [[John the Evangelist|Saint John the Evangelist]] is depicted as a young man accompanied by his traditional symbol the eagle and two [[putti]]. His gaze is directed upwards towards God as he receives the inspiration for his [[gospel]], emphasised by the strong [[chiaroscuro]] light bearing down upon him. This was typical of the artist's style, continuing in the manner of late [[Raphael]] and his own master [[Annibale Carracci]].
The composition is said to have been inspired by classical sculpture, with some commentators pointing specifically to [[Laocoön and His Sons|The Laocoon]].<ref name="christies">{{cite web|url=http://www.christies.com/LotFinder/lot_details.aspx?from=searchresults&intObjectID=5277781&sid=c6f04220-8a30-494e-be4f-fc7874d4c049|title=Domenico Zampieri, Il Domenichino (Bologna 1581-1641 Naples)|author=Christie?s|publisher=|accessdate=19 June 2015}}</ref> This is also evident in Domenichino's other large-scale treatments of the subject such as Madonna and Child with the Saints John the Evangelist and Petronius and the pendentive in the church of [[Sant'Andrea della Valle]]. The painting also includes an example of the artist's landscape painting, an aspect of his work that was particularly influential on the likes of [[Claude Lorrain]] and [[Nicolas Poussin]]. This element of the work was originally more compressed into the right-hand section of the canvas, the architecture taking precedence. However, Domenichino reconsidered this layout and over painted an extension of the landscape onto the wall. Other alterations are also visible in the books, the hand of the right putto and the larger hill of the landscape.

[[Ukiyo-e]] artists may be organized into [[Art movement|schools]], which consist of a founding artist and those artists who were taught by or strongly influenced by him. Artists of the Osaka school are united both stylistically and geographically.<ref>Assignment of artists into schools is derived from ''Hotei Encyclopedia of Japanese Woodblock Prints,'' 2005</ref> Not all of these artists designed [[Woodblock printing|woodblock prints]], and some ukiyo-e artists had more than one teacher, and others are not known to be associated with any particular school.

Films sans Frontières (France) | released = {{Film date|1965|10|18|Soviet Union|1967|03|16|U.S.|df=y}} | runtime = 97 minutes | country = Soviet Union | language = [[Ukrainian language|Ukrainian]] | music = [[Myroslav Skoryk]] | cinematography = Viktor Bestayev
Yuri Ilyenko }} '''''Shadows of Forgotten Ancestors''''' ({{lang-uk|Тіні забутих предків}}, ''Tini zabutykh predkiv''), also called ''Shadows of Our Forgotten Ancestors'', ''Shadows of Our Ancestors'', or ''Wild Horses of Fire'' – is a 1965{{cite book |last= Steffen |first=James |date=2013 |title= The Cinema of Sergei Parajanov |url= https://books.google.com/?id=RbDxAAAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=shadows+parajanov+september+1964#v=snippet&q=1964%20september&f=false |location=Madison |publisher= University of Wisconsin Press |isbn= 978-0-299-29653-7 |page="xvi}} film by the Soviet filmmaker [[Sergei Parajanov]] based on the classic book by Ukrainian writer [[Mykhailo Kotsiubynsky]]. The film was Parajanov's first major work and earned him international acclaim for its rich use of costume and color. The film also features a detailed portrayal of [[Ukrainians|Ukrainian]] [[Hutsul]] culture, showing not only the harsh [[Carpathian Mountains|Carpathian]] environment and brutal family rivalries, but also the various aspects of Hutsul traditions, music, costumes, and dialect. ==Plot== In a small [[Hutsul]] village in the [[Carpathian mountains]] of [[Ukraine]], a young man, Ivan, falls in love with the daughter of the man who killed his father. Though their families share a bitter enmity, Ivan and Marichka have known each other since childhood. In preparation for their marriage, Ivan leaves the village to work and earn money for a household. While he is gone, Marichka accidentally slips into a river and drowns while trying to rescue a lost lamb. Ivan returns and falls into despair after seeing Marichka's body. He continues to work, enduring a period of joyless toil, until he meets another woman, Palahna, while shoeing a horse. Ivan and Palahna get married in a traditional [[Hutsul]] wedding in which they are blindfolded and yoked together. The marriage quickly turns sour, however, as Ivan remains obsessed with the memory of Marichka. Estranged from her emotionally distant husband, Palahna becomes involved with a local sorcerer, while Ivan begins to experience hallucinations. At a tavern, Ivan witnesses the sorcerer embrace Palahna and strike one of his friends. Roused into an uncharacteristic fury, Ivan snatches up his axe, only to be struck down by the sorcerer. Ivan stumbles into the nearby woods and perceives Marichka's spirit to be with him, reflected in the water and gliding amongst the trees. As reality merges into dream, the colorless shade of Marichka reaches out across a great space and touches Ivan's outstretched hand. Ivan screams and dies. The community gives him a traditional Hutsul burial while children watch through cross braced windows. ==Themes== The film is highly symbolic, making frequent use of religious and folkloric images that include crosses, lambs, graves, and spirits. The film also uses color to represent mood. During Ivan's period of mourning, black and white film stock is used. In other scenes, colors are often muted, but provide a contrast to vivid use of red and yellow. On its release, the film's presentation contrasted with the common [[socialist realism]] style that had government approval. After refusing to change the film, Parajanov was soon blacklisted from Soviet cinema.[http://www.parajanov.com/maestro.html Sergei Paradzhanov] == Cast == * [[Ivan Mykolaichuk]] - Ivan * [[Larisa Kadochnikova]] - Marichka * {{Interlanguage link|Tatyana Bestayeva|ru|Бестаева, Татьяна Владимировна}} - Palagna * [[Spartak Bagashvili]] - Yurko * [[Nikolai Grinko]] - Batag * [[Leonid Yengibarov]] - Miko * [[Nina Alisova]] - Paliychuk ==Release== The film began an international film festival tour in Spring 1965.{{cite book |last= Steffen |first=James |date=2013 |title= The Cinema of Sergei Parajanov |url= https://books.google.com/?id=RbDxAAAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover |isbn=9780299296537 |page=73 }} Political protest followed the premiere of ''Shadows of Forgotten Ancestors'' in [[Kiev]] on 4 September 1975. The film was seen by 8.5 million viewers in the USSR.[http://ezhe.ru/cgi-bin/vgik-bd.cgi?g=g775] ==Filming== [[File:Carpathians-satellite.jpg|thumb|The film is set in the Ukrainian part of the [[Carpathian Mountains]].]] Parts of the film were shot in the [[Dovzhenko Film Studios]]. ==Awards== Grand Prix at Mar del Plata International Film Festival (1965). According to the Film Encyclopedia by Ephraim Katz, "Shadows of Forgotten Ancestors" received the British Academy Award (BAFTA) for "the best foreign production" but per the official statement from BAFTA, obtained by Sergei Parajanov's disciple [[Martiros Vartanov]], the film hadn't won or been nominated.[http://www.parajanov.com/shadowsofforgottenancestors.html Parajanov.com News ] ==In popular culture== The band [[A Hawk and a Hacksaw]] arranged their sixth studio album ''[[You Have Already Gone to the Other World]]'' as a new and original soundtrack to the movie. They played their soundtrack alongside the movie in cinemas and theatres in 2012. ==See also== * [[Verbovaya Doschechka]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|0058642}} *[http://www.parajanov.com/news.html Parajanov.com News] *[http://www.parajanov.com/shadowsofforgottenancestors.html Shadows of Forgotten Ancestors at Parajanov.com] {{Sergei Parajanov}} {{Ukraine topics}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Shadows Of Forgotten Ancestors}} [[Category:Soviet films]] [[Category:1964 films]] [[Category:Dovzhenko Film Studios films]] [[Category:Ukrainian films]] [[Category:Ukrainian-language films]] [[Category:Soviet-era Ukrainian films]] [[Category:Films set in Ukraine]] [[Category:Films directed by Sergei Parajanov]] [[Category:Art films]] [[Category:1960s drama films]]

The following is a '''list of unproduced Stephen Norrington projects''' in roughly chronological order. During a career that has spanned over 20 years, [[Stephen Norrington]] has worked on projects which never progressed beyond the [[pre-production]] stage under his direction. Many of the films were produced after he left production.
==1990s==
===''Blade II''=== * In 1999, Norrington was offered to direct ''[[Blade II]]'', the sequel to his [[Blade (film)|1998]] film.<ref>{{cite news|author=Michael Fleming|title=Helmer scales mountains|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117864489.html|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=March 25, 2002|accessdate=2008-12-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Ellen Wolff|title=Artists flaunt character development at confab|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117870028.html|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=July 21, 2002|accessdate=2008-12-16}}</ref> He turned it down, resulting in the studio hiring [[Guillermo del Toro]] to replace him.<ref>{{cite website|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/blade_2_bloodhunt/|title=Blade 2 Movie Reviews, Pictures|publisher=Rotten Tomatoes|accessdate=2011-01-06}}</ref>
==2000s==
===''Ghost Rider''=== * In 2001, Norrington was originally attached to [[Dimension Films]]'s ''[[Ghost Rider (2007 film)|Ghost Rider]]'' before the project was acquired by [[Columbia Pictures]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bloody-disgusting.com/news/18676|title=WWII Backdrop, Monsters and 'The Lost Patrol'|publisher=BloodyDisgusting}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Michael|first=Fleming|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117785776.html?categoryid=13&cs=1|title='Ghost' adds a Dimension|publisher=''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]''|date=2000-08-30|accessdate=2006-12-22 }}</ref> The film was eventually released in 2007 directed by [[Mark Steven Johnson]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Harris|first=Dana|url=http://www.variety.com/index.asp?layout=story&articleid=VR1117884327&categoryid=13&cs=1|title=Johnson sees 'Ghost'|publisher=''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]''|date=2003-04-08|accessdate=2006-12-22}}</ref>
===''The Hands of Shang-Chi''=== * In 2001, Norrington announced that he had agreed to direct a film based on ''The Hands of Shang-Chi: Master of Kung Fu'', a film adaptation based on the Marvel character ''[[:w:c:marvel:Shang-Chi|Shang-Chi]]''. Norrington described the film as "a real honest-to-goodness martial arts film, rather than a film that simply has martial arts in it". In 2004, it was announced that [[Ang Lee]] had been brought on as producer. In 2005, it was announced that Stan Lee had agreed to executive produce the film for DreamWorks, with Yuen Woo-ping directing from a Bruce McKenna screenplay.<ref name="leechiback">[http://blog.moviefone.com/2006/02/27/ang-lees-shang-chi-movie-is-back/ Ang Lee's Shang-Chi movie is back]</ref> In 2005, [[Avi Arad]] stated that he thought that a PG-13 adaptation was possible.<ref>[http://www.mtv.com/shared/movies/interviews/a/arad_avi_062005/ Future Shocks: What's Ahead For Avi Arad and his Marvel empire?]</ref> In 2006, Ang Lee confirmed his and Yuen's continued involvement with the project.<ref name="leechiback" /> However, no further developments have been announced to date.
===''Akira'' remake=== * Shortly after Warner Bros. acquired the rights in 2002, Stephen Norrington was slated to direct a remake to the 1988 film ''[[Akira (1988 film)|Akira]]'', with [[James Robinson (writer)|James Robinson]] writing the screenplay and [[Dan Lin]] producing.<ref name="ign la 2017">{{cite web | url = http://www.ign.com/articles/2017/04/06/akira-the-tortured-history-of-the-unmade-live-action-adaptation | title = Akira: The Tortured History of he Unmade Live-Action Adaptation | first = Christopher | last = Marc | date = April 6, 2017 | accessdate = August 31, 2017 | work = [[IGN]] }}</ref><ref>[http://www.ign.com/articles/2002/04/12/akira-hollywood-remake]</ref> Norrington had planned to make the remake more appealing to Western audiences, making Kaneda and Tetsuo brothers. Following the commercial failure of ''[[The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen (film)|The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen]]'' in 2003, which both Norrington and Robinson were also on, the project was put on hold.<ref name="ign la 2017"/>
===''The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen'' (sequel and reboot)=== * In 2003, Norrington's ''[[The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen (film)|The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen]]'' was intended to spawn a [[Media franchise|film franchise]] based on further titles in the original comic book series, but there was little enthusiasm for a sequel due to performing poorly at the box office.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.the-numbers.com/movies/2003/TLOEG.php|title=The Numbers: Box Office Data|publisher=|accessdate=October 4, 2014}}</ref> After the sequel was scrapped, ''The Tracking Board'' reported, on May 26, 2015, that 20th Century Fox and [[Davis Entertainment]] had agreed to develop a reboot with hopes of launching a new franchise. The report stated that a search was underway for a director who could help "continue to develop the reboot".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tracking-board.com/tb-exclusive-fox-enters-development-on-a-reboot-of-the-league-of-extraordinary-gentlemen/|title={TB EXCLUSIVE} Fox Enters Development on "The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen" Reboot – The Tracking Board|work=The Tracking Board}}</ref> [[John Davis (producer)|John Davis]] told Collider in an interview that the reboot will be a female-centric film.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://collider.com/league-of-extraordinary-gentlemen-reboot-female-centric/|title='League of Extraordinary Gentlemen' Reboot to Be Female-Centric|publisher=Collider|last=Goldberg|first=Matt|date=August 13, 2015}}</ref> Since then, there has not been any further announcements, falling into development hell.
===''Clash of the Titans'' (2010)=== * In 2007, Norrington was originally set to direct the remake of the 1981 fantasy film ''[[Clash of the Titans (2010 film)|Clash of the Titans]]''. However, Norrington was unsure about his direction for the project because he did not grow up with the original. [[Louis Leterrier]], who did, contacted Norrington through their shared agent about replacing him. Leterrier's film was released in 2010.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Crow To Fly Again: LXG's Norrington to write, direct|url=http://www.empireonline.com/news/story.asp?NID=23871|date=15 December 2008|accessdate=13 January 2009|publisher=Empire Online}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |author=Fleming, Michael |url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117977672.html?categoryid=1238&cs=1 |title=Norrington to direct ''Titans'' |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |date=2007-12-13 |accessdate=2008-11-08}}</ref>
===''The Crow'' (reboot)=== * In 2008, it was announced that Norrington would direct a reboot of ''[[The Crow#In_other_media|The Crow]]'' franchise.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bloody-disgusting.com/news/19918|title='The Crow' Redo Flying Back to Detroit?|publisher=BloodyDisgusting}}</ref> He left the film by 2013 and was replaced by [[F. Javier Gutiérrez]].<ref>{{Cite web|first=Sean CW|last=Korsgaard|title=Interview with James O'Barr, creator of The Crow|website=korsgaardscommentary.com|date=October 30, 2014|url=http://www.korsgaardscommentary.com/2014/10/interview-james-obarr-creator-crow.html|accessdate=November 15, 2014}}</ref> By July 2015, Gutiérrez eventually left the project and was replaced by [[Corin Hardy]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.screengeek.net/2017/10/29/the-crow-reboot-to-begin-pre-production-in-february/ |title=Exclusive: The Crow Reboot To Begin Pre-Production In February |last=Salcido |first=Mark |date=2017-10-29 |website=Screengeek |access-date=2017-10-30}}</ref> Hardy also left the project on May 31, 2018, leaving the film in limbo.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.slashfilm.com/the-crow-remake-dead/|title='The Crow' Remake is Dead Again as Jason Momoa and Corin Hardy Exit|date=2018-05-31|work=/Film|access-date=2018-05-31|language=en-US}}</ref>
==2010s==
===''The Lost Patrol''=== * In 2010, Norrington was going to direct and write the supernatural action thriller ''The Lost Patrol'' to be distributed by [[Legendary Pictures]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dreadcentral.com/news/35313/stephen-norrington-helm-the-lost-patrol-wwii-plus-monsters|title=Stephen Norrington to Helm The Lost Patrol - WWII Plus Monsters!|publisher=DreadCentral}}</ref> Since then, there has not been any further development.

The following is '''a list of unproduced [[Steven Spielberg]] projects''' in roughly chronological order. During his long career, American film director [[Steven Spielberg]] has worked on a number of projects which never progressed beyond the pre-production stage under his direction. Some of these projects fell in [[development hell]], were officially canceled, or were in [[development limbo]].
== 1970s == === ''Flushed with Pride: The Story of Thomas Crapper'' === At the beginning of the 1970s, Spielberg tried to greenlight the production of ''Flushed with Pride: The Story of Thomas Crapper'', the semi-satirical biography of [[Thomas Crapper]], who, as the book suggested, invented the flushing toilet. Spielberg approached screenwriters [[Gloria Katz]] and [[Willard Huyck]] to write the script.<ref name="Awalt2014">{{cite book|author=Steven Awalt|title=Steven Spielberg and Duel: The Making of a Film Career|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yjsfAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA40&dq=Flushed|date=14 March 2014|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield Publishers|isbn=978-0-8108-9261-3|page=40}}</ref> However, the film was never made due to various problems, so Spielberg left the project to direct ''[[The Sugarland Express]]''.
=== ''Cruising'' === In the early 1970s, film producer [[Philip D'Antoni]] hired Spielberg to direct a film adaptation of Gerald Walker's novel ''[[Cruising (novel)|Cruising]]''.<ref name=gingold>{{cite web|last=Gingold|first=Michael|title=Steven Spielberg’s Strange History With ‘Cruising’|date=15 February 2017|publisher=[[IndieWire]]|url=https://www.indiewire.com/2017/02/steven-spielberg-cruising-al-pacino-1201783514/|accessdate=26 August 2018}}</ref> Spielberg was reportedly attached to the project for three years before officially dropping out.<ref>{{cite web|last=Malkin|first=Marc|title=No ''Cruising'' for Steven Spielberg|date=30 August 2007|publisher=''[[E! News]]''|url=https://www.eonline.com/news/59449/no-cruising-for-steven-spielberg|accessdate=26 August 2018}}</ref> According to D'Antoni, "We just couldn’t come up with a script that met with my satisfaction... So we decided to abandon the project, and figured we’d go on to do something else together some other day, and Steven went back to LA.”<ref name=gingold/> The [[Cruising (film)|film adaptation]] was eventually directed by [[William Friedkin]].<ref>{{cite web|title=William Friedkin: ‘Cruising’ Was Almost Directed By Steven Spielberg (VIDEO)|date=3 May 2013|publisher=''[[HuffPost]]''|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/05/03/william-friedkin-cruising_n_3204257.html|accessdate=26 August 2018}}</ref>
=== ''Lucky Lady'' === Spielberg was considered to direct ''[[Lucky Lady]]'' for [[20th Century Fox]]. The script was written by Huyck and Katz and [[Paul Newman]] was to have starred in the film had Spielberg directed. However, Spielberg could not direct the film due to his commitment with ''Jaws''.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yjsfAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA183&lpg=PA183&dq=steven+spielberg+lucky+lady&source=bl&ots=z_gd0zZB-_&sig=QEotz3UyVhJqF3h7qYHscuA_UUQ&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjOkvH9mqfcAhWD94MKHVrpDks4ChDoAQg-MAM#v=onepage&q=steven%20spielberg%20lucky%20lady&f=false|last=Awalt|first=Steven|title=Steven Spielberg and Duel: The Making of a Film Career|year=2014|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|isbn=9780810892613}}page 183</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Freer|first=Ian|title=Steven Spielberg's Interstellar?! The 19 Films He Nearly Made|date=9 May 2014|publisher=''[[Empire (film magazine)]]''|url=https://www.empireonline.com/movies/features/unmade-spielberg-movies/|accessdate=17 July 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=FORTUNE AND GLORY: Writers of Doom! Quint interviews Willard Huyck and Gloria Katz!|date=23 May 2014|publisher=[[Ain't It Cool News]]|url=http://www.aintitcool.com/node/67450|accessdate=17 July 2018}}</ref>
=== ''Superman: The Movie'' === Around 1975, after the success of ''[[Jaws (film)|Jaws]]'', [[Alexander Salkind]] and his son [[Ilya Salkind|Ilya]] wanted to hire Spielberg to direct ''[[Superman (1978 film)|Superman: The Movie]]'', the first theatrical movie based on the [[Superman]] comic book series. However, due to Spielberg's commitment to ''[[Close Encounters of the Third Kind]]'', the Salkinds finally hired [[Richard Donner]] to direct the film.<ref>{{cite interview|url=http://www.supermanhomepage.com/movies/movies.php?topic=interview-salkind|title=One-on-One Interview with Producer Ilya Salkind|author=Barry M. Freiman|date=|website=www.supermanhomepage.com}}</ref>
=== ''The Adventures of Indiana Smith'' === In May 1977, Spielberg met his colleague [[George Lucas]] in [[Hawaii]]. During that vacation, Lucas convinced Spielberg to make a film based on the [[Movie serial|film serials]] of the 1930s and 1940s. Lucas previously wrote a script for the planned film, entitled ''The Adventures of Indiana Smith''; in which the main character, Indiana Smith, was based on [[James Bond]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/news/2008/02/spielberg_qanda200802?currentPage=4|title=Q&A: Steven Spielberg on Indiana Jones|first=Jim|last=Windolf|date=|website=vanityfair.com}}</ref> However, at the final moment, both Lucas and Spielberg made many changes to the script, whose concept was used to create ''[[Raiders of the Lost Ark]]'', and subsequently, the [[Indiana Jones (franchise)|''Indiana Jones'' film franchise]].
=== ''Close Encounters of the Third Kind 2'' === In late 1977, after the successful reception of ''[[Close Encounters of the Third Kind]]'', Spielberg expressed interest in filming a [[Close Encounters of the Third Kind#Legacy|sequel or a prequel]]. However, he later refused the idea, because he felt that "The army's knowledge and ensuing [[cover-up]] is so subterranean that it would take a creative screen story, perhaps someone else making the picture and giving it the equal time it deserves". He also didn't want developer [[Columbia Pictures]] to make a sequel without him, which had happened with [[Universal Pictures]]' ''[[Jaws (film)|Jaws]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.denofgeek.com/us/movies/et/236015/how-steven-spielbergs-night-skies-became-et|title=How Steven Spielberg's Night Skies Became E.T.|author=|date=|website=denofgeek.com}}</ref>
=== ''Magic'' === In the late 1970s, Spielberg expressed interest in directing a film adaptation of [[William Goldman]]'s novel ''[[Magic (novel)|Magic]]'' and considered casting [[Robert De Niro]] for the lead role.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lBz7pwx2I-oC&pg=PT306&dq=steven+spielberg+robert+de+niro+magic&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjq7aLO5brdAhVSnlkKHYVHBtYQ6AEIMzAC#v=onepage&q=steven%20spielberg%20robert%20de%20niro%20magic&f=false|last=Dougan|first=Andy|title=Untouchable: Robert De Niro: Unauthorised|year=2011|publisher=Random House|isbn=9780753546840}}{{page needed|date=September 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Schager|first=Nick|title=14 Major Movies That Were ALMOST Directed by Steven Spielberg|date=1 October 2015|publisher=[[Yahoo!]]|url=https://www.yahoo.com/entertainment/news/14-major-movies-that-were-almost-made-by-steven-155957788.html|accessdate=14 September 2018}}</ref> The [[Magic (1978 film)|film]] ended up being directed by [[Richard Attenborough]] and Spielberg admitted, "...I went to see the picture and realized that it was a hell of a lot better than what I would have done."<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jf9HBgttTeQC&pg=PA296&dq=steven+spielberg+robert+de+niro+magic&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjq7aLO5brdAhVSnlkKHYVHBtYQ6AEIOTAD#v=onepage&q=steven%20spielberg%20robert%20de%20niro%20magic&f=false|last=McBride|first=Joseph|title=Steven Spielberg: A Biography, Second Edition|year=2011|publisher=Univ. Press of Mississippi|isbn=9781604738377}}page 296</ref>
=== ''Night Skies'' === {{main|Night Skies}} After his decision not to make a sequel to ''[[Close Encounters of the Third Kind]]'', Spielberg started the development of his next project, a [[Science fiction films|science fiction]] [[horror film]] entitled ''[[Night Skies]]'', whose concept was pitched by him during the development of ''Close Encounters''. The film was intended to be a spiritual [[Sequel|follow-up]] to ''Close Encounters''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.slashfilm.com/rick-baker-night-skies-aliens/|title=See the Rick Baker Night Skies Aliens - /Film|author=|date=26 May 2014|website=slashfilm.com}}</ref> [[Lawrence Kasdan]] was attached to write the screenplay. However, the film wasn't made, although the main concept was the inspiration of two Spielberg's films: ''[[Poltergeist (1982 film)|Poltergeist]]'' and ''[[E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial]]'' (although the first wasn't directed by Spielberg).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2002/mar/15/artsfeatures.stevenspielberg|title=Alien resurrection|first=David|last=Thomson|date=15 March 2002|website=the Guardian}}</ref>
== 1980s == === ''Blackhawk'' === In the early 1980s, Spielberg announced that he had plans to direct a film adaptation of the [[Blackhawk (DC Comics)|Blackhawk]] comic book series. [[Dan Aykroyd]] was attached to play Blackhawk.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cosmicteams.com/quality/evanier-Interview.html|title=Justice Society of America|author=|date=|website=www.cosmicteams.com}}</ref> However, the project never materialized and Spielberg chose to direct ''[[Raiders of the Lost Ark]]''. In April 2018, new development emerged when it was announced that Spielberg will produce/direct a new film adaptation of ''Blackhawk'' for [[Warner Bros.]], with the screenplay being written by [[David Koepp]]. Spielberg will co-produce the film with [[Kristie Macosko Krieger]] and Sue Kroll.<ref>https://variety.com/2018/film/news/steven-spielberg-blackhawk-dc-1202756319/</ref><ref>http://ew.com/movies/2018/04/17/steven-spielberg-blackhawk/</ref>
=== ''Reel to Reel'' === Around 1980, during the filming of ''[[Raiders of the Lost Ark]]'', Spielberg contacted [[Gary David Goldberg]] to make a semiautobiographical musical film entitled ''Reel to Reel''. The film's plot would have been surrounding a filmmaker named Stuart Moss, and his direction of a musical remake of ''[[Invaders from Mars (1953 film)|Invaders From Mars]]''.<ref name="McBride2012">{{cite book|author=Joseph McBride|title=Steven Spielberg: A Biography (Third Edition)|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cbbJgbdwUFkC&pg=PT242&dq=reel+to+reel+steven+spielberg|date=1 September 2012|publisher=Faber & Faber|isbn=978-0-571-28055-1|page=242}}</ref> The film was officially announced in production in 1983, but Spielberg finally abandoned the project and chose to direct ''[[Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indiewire.com/2015/10/the-lost-unmade-projects-of-steven-spielberg-112055/|title=The Lost & Unmade Projects Of Steven Spielberg|first=Oliver|last=Lyttelton|date=14 October 2015|website=indiewire.com}}</ref>
=== ''Three Amigos'' === After he finished ''Raiders of the Lost Ark'', Spielberg almost planned to direct the comedy ''[[Three Amigos]]'' next, with [[Steve Martin]], [[Bill Murray]] and [[Robin Williams]] as the leads. He chose to direct ''E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial'' instead.<ref>{{cite web|last=Evans|first=Bradford|title=The Lost Roles of Three Amigos|date=15 December 2011|publisher=[[Vulture.com]]|url=http://www.vulture.com/2011/12/the-lost-roles-of-three-amigos.html|accessdate=17 July 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Green|first=Anna|title=15 Infamous Facts About ¡Three Amigos!|date=12 May 2015|publisher=''[[Mental Floss]]''|url=http://mentalfloss.com/article/68307/15-infamous-facts-about-three-amigos|accessdate=17 July 2018}}</ref>
=== ''E.T. II: Nocturnal Fears'' === In July 1982, Spielberg hired ''[[E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial]]'' writer [[Melissa Mathison]] to write a script for a sequel film, entitled ''E.T. II: Nocturnal Fears''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://birthmoviesdeath.com/2015/04/13/the-incredibly-ill-advised-e.t.-sequel-that-almost-was|title=The Incredibly Ill-Advised E.T. Sequel That Almost Was|first=Scott|last=Wampler|date=13 April 2015|website=birthmoviesdeath.com}}</ref> The film's plot would have shown Elliott and his friends getting kidnapped by evil aliens and follow their attempts to contact E.T. for help. However, Spielberg finally decided to cancel the sequel's production, feeling it "would do nothing but rob the original of its virginity".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/latimes/doc/154308595.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&type=historic&date=&author=&pub=&edition=&startpage=&desc=|title= E.T. RETURNS TO TEST HIS MIDAS TOUCH|work=Los Angeles Times|author=Wilson, John M|date=Jun 16, 1985}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.blastr.com/2015-5-20/look-et-sequel-we-mercifully-never-saw|title=A look at the E.T. sequel we mercifully never saw|first=Carol|last=Pinchefsky|date=20 May 2015|website=blastr.com}}</ref>
=== ''Indiana Jones and the Monkey King'' === In September 1984, after the critical and mixed reception of ''[[Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom]]'', [[George Lucas]] wrote a script entitled ''Indiana Jones and the Monkey King'' for the third installment of the film series.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mentalfloss.com/article/31313/lost-scripts-part-i-indiana-jones-and-monkey-king|title=The Lost Scripts, Part I: Indiana Jones and the Monkey King|author=|date=26 July 2012|website=mentalfloss.com}}</ref> The film had the [[Fountain of Youth]] as the [[MacGuffin]]. Spielberg was attached to direct, but at the final moment, Spielberg decided to hire [[Chris Columbus (filmmaker)|Chris Columbus]] to rewrite the script, and the third film ended up being ''[[Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.denofgeek.com/movies/indiana-jones/29092/the-indiana-jones-films-that-never-happened|title=The Indiana Jones films that never happened|author=|date=|website=denofgeek.com}}</ref>
=== ''Rain Man'' === Spielberg was among the few filmmakers attached to direct ''[[Rain Man]]'' prior to [[Barry Levinson]]'s official involvement.<ref>{{cite web|last=Horn|first=John|title=`RAIN MAN' - THE ROLE HOFFMAN ALMOST QUIT|date=29 December 1988|publisher=''[[Deseret News]]''|url=https://www.deseretnews.com/article/28856/RAIN-MAN---THE-ROLE-HOFFMAN-ALMOST-QUIT.html|accessdate=26 August 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Papamichael|first=Stella|title=Rain Man: Special Edition DVD (1988)|date=16 August 2004|publisher=[[BBC]]|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/films/2004/08/16/rain_man_se_2004_dvd_review.shtml|accessdate=26 August 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Klein|first=Joshua|title=Obstacles didn't put damper on `Rain Man's' numbers|date=10 February 2004|publisher=''[[Chicago Tribune]]''|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2004-02-10/features/0402100007_1_disc-classics-sydney-pollack|accessdate=26 August 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Rensin|first=David|title=Barry Levinson on the Making of ‘Rain Man’|date=12 January 1989|publisher=''[[Rolling Stone]]''|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/movies/movie-features/barry-levinson-on-the-making-of-rain-man-66029/|accessdate=26 August 2018}}</ref> It was Spielberg who convinced screenwriter [[Ronald Bass]] to make the character of Raymond Babbitt as an autistic savant.<ref>{{cite web|last=Tobias|first=Scott|title=Rain Man (DVD)|date=10 February 2004|publisher=''[[The A.V. Club]]''|url=https://film.avclub.com/rain-man-dvd-1798199327|accessdate=26 August 2018}}</ref> Spielberg dropped out as he was obligated to direct ''Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade''.<ref>{{cite web|last=Kornbluth|first=Jesse|title=FROM ''TIN MEN'' TO ''RAIN MAN''|date=December 1988|publisher=''[[Vanity Fair (magazine)]]''|url=https://www.vanityfair.com/news/1988/12/hollywood-code-198812|accessdate=26 August 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Cochrane|first=Emma|title=Rain Man Review|date=1 January 2000|publisher=''[[Empire (film magazine)]]''|url=https://www.empireonline.com/movies/rain-man/review/|accessdate=26 August 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Caulfield|first=Deborah|title=Hoffman and Pollack Back at the Movie-Making Gate Again : Prize-Winning Bickerers From 'Tootsie' Days Join Forces With Tom Cruise to Start 'Rainman'|date=20 November 1987|publisher=''[[Los Angeles Times]]''|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1987-11-20/entertainment/ca-15334_1_tootsie|accessdate=26 August 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Obias|first=Rudie|title=12 Movies Steven Spielberg Almost Made|date=7 April 2016|publisher=''[[Mental Floss]]''|url=http://mentalfloss.com/article/60761/12-movies-steven-spielberg-almost-made|accessdate=26 August 2018}}</ref> Spielberg regrets not directing ''Rain Man''.<ref>{{cite web|last=Guidry|first=Ken|title=Watch: 36-Minute 1990 Interview With Steven Spielberg, Regrets Passing On ‘Rain Man’ For ‘Indy 3’ & More|date=11 June 2013|publisher=[[IndieWire]]|url=https://www.indiewire.com/2013/06/watch-36-minute-1990-interview-with-steven-spielberg-regrets-passing-on-rain-man-for-indy-3-more-97112/|accessdate=26 August 2018}}</ref>
=== ''Who Discovered Roger Rabbit'' === In 1989, Spielberg discussed with [[J.J. Abrams]] the possibilites of making a sequel to the successful ''[[Who Framed Roger Rabbit]]'' feature film.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nerdist.com/nerdist-podcast-j-j-abrams-and-dan-trachtenberg/|title=Nerdist Podcast: J.J. Abrams and Dan Trachtenberg - Nerdist|author=|date=11 March 2016|website=nerdist.com}}</ref> The sequel's plot would have been Roger Rabbit, Baby Herman, and Richie Davenport traveling west to seek Roger's mother, in the process meeting Jessica Krupnick (Roger's future wife), a struggling Hollywood actress. While Roger and Ritchie are enlisting in the Army, Jessica is kidnapped and forced to make pro-[[Nazi Germany]] broadcasts.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.filmbuffonline.com/FBOLNewsreel/wordpress/2005/08/07/script-review-roger-rabbit-ii-the-toon-platoon/|title=Script Review: ROGER RABBIT II: THE TOON PLATOON - FilmBuffOnline|author=|date=7 August 2005|website=filmbuffonline.com}}</ref> The film would also have been the first true film from [[Amblin Entertainment]]'s animation division [[Amblimation]]. However, after directing ''[[Schindler's List]]'', Spielberg refused to direct any films satirizing the Nazis.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2008/04/18/spielberg-lucas-titans-talk|title=Spielberg & Lucas: The titans talk!|author=|date=|website=ew.com}}</ref> [[Michael Eisner]] commissioned a rewrite in 1997 with [[Sherri Stoner]] and [[Deanna Oliver]]. Although they kept Roger's search for his mother, Stoner and Oliver replaced the WWII subplot with Roger's inadvertent rise to stardom on [[Broadway (Manhattan)|Broadway]] and Hollywood. Disney was impressed and [[Alan Menken]] was hired to write five songs for the film and offered his services as executive producer. One of the songs, "This Only Happens in the Movies", was recorded in 2008 on the debut album of Broadway actress [[Kerry Butler]].<ref>{{cite news | url = http://broadwayworld.com/viewcolumn.cfm?colid=25560 | title = Kerry Butler's 'Faith, Trust and Pixie Dust' Set For May Release | work = Broadway World | date = February 28, 2008 | accessdate = November 4, 2008}}</ref> [[Eric Goldberg (film director)|Eric Goldberg]] was set to be the new animation director, and began to redesign Roger's new character appearance.
Spielberg became busy establishing [[DreamWorks]], while Frank Marshall and Kathleen Kennedy decided to remain as producers. Test footage for ''Who Discovered Roger Rabbit'' was shot sometime in 1998 at the Disney animation unit in [[Lake Buena Vista, Florida]]; the results were a mix of CGI, traditional animation, and live-action that did not please Disney. A second test had the Toons completely converted to [[computer-generated imagery|CGI]]; but this was dropped as the film's projected budget would escalate past $100 million. Eisner felt it was best to cancel the film. In March 2003, producer [[Don Hahn]] was doubtful about a sequel being made, arguing that public tastes had changed since the 1990s with the rise of computer animation. "There was something very special about that time when animation was not as much in the forefront as it is now."<ref>{{cite news |author =Staff| url = https://www.usatoday.com/life/movies/news/2003-03-26-rabbit_x.htm | title = Don't expect a ''Rabbit'' sequel | work = [[USA Today]] | date = March 26, 2003 | accessdate = September 5, 2014}}</ref>
In December 2007, Marshall stated that he was still "open" to the idea,<ref name="Frank">{{cite news | url = http://moviesblog.mtv.com/2007/12/11/roger-rabbit-sequel-still-in-the-offing-stay-tooned-says-producer/ | title = ''Roger Rabbit'' Sequel Still In The Offing? Stay Tooned, Says Producer | author = Shawn Adler | date = September 11, 2007 | work = [[MTV]] Movies Blog | accessdate = November 4, 2008 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20121017173326/http://moviesblog.mtv.com/2007/12/11/roger-rabbit-sequel-still-in-the-offing-stay-tooned-says-producer/ | archivedate = October 17, 2012 | df = mdy-all }}</ref> and in April 2009, Zemeckis revealed he was still interested.<ref>{{cite news|author=Eric Ditzian|title=Robert Zemeckis 'Buzzing' About Second 'Roger Rabbit' Movie|work=[[MTV]] Movies Blog|date=April 29, 2009|url=http://moviesblog.mtv.com/2009/04/29/exclusive-robert-zemeckis-buzzing-about-second-roger-rabbit-movie/|accessdate=April 29, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120627064600/http://moviesblog.mtv.com/2009/04/29/exclusive-robert-zemeckis-buzzing-about-second-roger-rabbit-movie|archivedate=June 27, 2012|df=mdy-all}}</ref> According to a 2009 [[MTV News]] story, Jeffrey Price and Peter S. Seaman were writing a new script for the project, and the animated characters would be in traditional two-dimensional, while the rest would be in [[motion capture]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://moviesblog.mtv.com/2009/11/03/exclusive-robert-zemeckis-indicates-hell-use-performance-capture-and-3-d-in-roger-rabbit-sequel/ |title=EXCLUSIVE: Robert Zemeckis Indicates He'll Use Performance-Capture And 3-D In 'Roger Rabbit' Sequel |publisher=Moviesblog.mtv.com |accessdate=November 12, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101103072903/http://moviesblog.mtv.com/2009/11/03/exclusive-robert-zemeckis-indicates-hell-use-performance-capture-and-3-d-in-roger-rabbit-sequel/ |archivedate=November 3, 2010 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> However, in 2010, Zemeckis said that the sequel would remain hand-drawn animated and live-action sequences will be filmed, just like in the original film, but the lighting effects on the cartoon characters and some of the props that the Toons handle will be done digitally.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://toontownantics.blogspot.com/2010/07/roger-rabbit-2-in-3d.html |title=Toontown Antics - Roger Rabbit's adventures in real and animated life: Roger Rabbit 2 – In 3D? |publisher=Toontownantics.blogspot.com |date=July 20, 2010 |accessdate=November 12, 2011}}</ref> Also in 2010, Don Hahn, who was the film's original associate producer, confirmed the sequel's development in an interview with ''[[Empire (magazine)|Empire]]''. He stated, "Yeah, I couldn't possibly comment. I deny completely, but yeah... if you're a fan, pretty soon you're going to be very, very, very happy."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.empireonline.com/news/story.asp?NID=28191 |title=Exclusive: The Lion King To Go 3D! | Movie News | Empire |publisher=Empireonline.com |accessdate=November 12, 2011}}</ref> In 2010, [[Bob Hoskins]] stated he was interested in the project, reprising his role as Eddie Valiant. However, he retired from acting in 2012 after being diagnosed with [[Parkinson's disease]] a year earlier, and died from complications in 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.itv.com/news/update/2012-08-08/bob-hoskins-retires-from-acting/ |title=Bob Hoskins retires from acting |publisher=Itv.com |date=August 8, 2012 |accessdate=August 24, 2014}}</ref> Marshall has confirmed that the film is a prequel, similar to earlier drafts, and that the writing was almost complete.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://collider.com/frank-marshall-roger-rabbit-2-sequel-bourne-legacy/187006/ |title=Frank Marshall Talks WHO FRAMED ROGER RABBIT 2 Sequel, THE BOURNE LEGACY, THE GOONIES 2, More |publisher=Collider |accessdate=October 18, 2012}}</ref> During an interview at the premiere of ''[[Flight (2012 film)|Flight]]'', Zemeckis stated that the sequel was still possible, despite Hoskins' absence, and the script for the sequel was sent to Disney for approval from studio executives.<ref>{{cite web|last=Fischer|first=Russ|title=Despite Bob Hoskins' Retirement, the 'Roger Rabbit' Sequel is Still Possible|url=http://www.slashfilm.com/despite-bob-hoskins-retirement-the-roger-rabbit-sequel-is-still-possible/|publisher=[[SlashFilm|/Film]]|accessdate=October 16, 2012}}</ref>
In February 2013, Gary K. Wolf, writer of the original novel, said Erik Von Wodtke and he were working on a development proposal for an animated Disney buddy comedy starring Mickey Mouse and Roger Rabbit called ''The Stooge'', based on [[The Stooge|the 1952 film of the same name]]. The proposed film is set to a prequel, taking place five years before ''Who Framed Roger Rabbit'' and part of the story is about how Roger met Jessica, his future wife. Wolf has stated the film is currently wending its way through Disney.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dvdizzy.com/forum/viewtopic.php?f=1&t=30567 |title=• View topic - Mickey Mouse & Roger Rabbit in The Stooge |publisher=Dvdizzy.com |accessdate=August 24, 2014}}</ref> In November 2016, while promoting his latest film ''[[Allied (film)|Allied]]'', in England, Zemeckis stated that the sequel "moves the story of Roger and Jessica Rabbit into the next few years of period film, moving on from film noir to the world of the 1950s". He also stated that the sequel would feature a "digital Bob Hoskins", as Eddie Valiant would return in "ghost form". While the director went on to state that the script is "terrific" and the film would still use hand-drawn animation, Zemeckis thinks that the chances of Disney green-lighting the sequel are "slim". As he explained more in detail, "The current corporate Disney culture [the current studio management of [[The Walt Disney Company]]] has no interest in Roger, and they certainly don't like Jessica at all."<ref>{{cite web|last=Brew|first=Simon|title=Who Framed Roger Rabbit 2 would include "digital Bob Hoskins"|url=http://www.denofgeek.com/uk/movies/who-framed-roger-rabbit-2/45599/who-framed-roger-rabbit-2-would-include-digital-bob-hoskins|publisher=Den of Geek|accessdate=November 29, 2016}}</ref>
== 1990s ==
=== ''Why Can't I Be Audrey Hepburn?'' === According to [[Ryan Murphy (writer)|Ryan Murphy]] on his appearance on the radio program ''[[Fresh Air with Terry Gross]]'', Ryan sold a script he made for Spielberg called ''Why Can't I Be Audrey Hepburn?'' about a woman obsessed with famous film actress [[Audrey Hepburn]] who has left at the altar who then meets a man just as Audrey-centric as she. The film was going to star [[Téa Leoni]] and [[Jennifer Love Hewitt]] as different roles. Spielberg was interested in making it, but the film's production was canceled after nothing new came out of it and Spielberg had a lot of other projects in the 90's he was busy working on.
=== ''Cape Fear'' === In the early stages of development, Spielberg was slated to direct the [[Cape Fear (1991 film)|remake]] of the 1962 film ''[[Cape Fear (1962 film)|Cape Fear]]'' whereas [[Martin Scorsese]] would direct ''[[Schindler's List]]'' (1993).<ref>{{cite web|title=Unforgettable Scene: De Niro's Cape Fear Seduction|date=7 October 2011|publisher=''[[Entertainment Weekly]]''|url=https://ew.com/article/2011/10/07/unforgettable-scene-de-niros-cape-fear-seduction/|accessdate=18 August 2018}}</ref> Had Spielberg directed, he envisioned the roles of [[Max Cady]] and Sam Bowden to be portrayed by [[Bill Murray]] and [[Harrison Ford]] respectively.<ref name=cf>{{cite web|last=Baldwin|first=Daniel|title=[Exhumed & Exonerated] ‘Cape Fear’ (1991)|date=27 October 2016|publisher=[[Bloody Disgusting]]|url=https://bloody-disgusting.com/editorials/3410947/exhumed-exonerated-cape-fear-1991/|accessdate=18 August 2018}}</ref> Spielberg eventually decided to swap projects with Scorsese in favor of directing ''Schindler's List'' instead.<ref>{{cite web|last=Collin|first=Robbie|title=The 10 greatest films almost made|date=26 September 2014|publisher=''[[The Daily Telegraph]]''|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/film/film-news/11006358/What-if-Scorsese-had-made-Schindlers-List.html|accessdate=18 August 2018}}</ref> Although uncredited, Spielberg did remain as a producer of the remake.<ref name=cf/>
=== ''Shrek'' === In 1991, Spielberg bought the rights to [[William Steig]]'s 1990 children's book ''[[Shrek!]]''. Spielberg originally envisioned his adaptation as a [[Traditional animation|traditional animated]] film from [[Amblin Entertainment]], with [[Bill Murray]] as the voice of the [[Shrek (character)|titular character]] and [[Steve Martin]] as the voice of [[Donkey (Shrek)|Donkey]]. Despite co-founding [[DreamWorks Animation]]—the eventual owner of the [[Shrek (franchise)|''Shrek'' franchise]]—in 1994, Spielberg moved on to other projects.<ref>{{cite web|last=Cormier|first=Roger|title=15 Giant Facts About Shrek|date=22 March 2016|publisher=''[[Mental Floss]]''|url=http://mentalfloss.com/article/64343/15-giant-facts-about-shrek|accessdate=17 July 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Denninger|first=Lindsay|title=5 Actors Almost Cast In 'Shrek,' Because Mike Myers Wasn't Supposed To Voice The Ogre|date=18 May 2016|publisher=''[[Bustle (magazine)]]''|url=https://www.bustle.com/articles/160924-5-actors-almost-cast-in-shrek-because-mike-myers-wasnt-supposed-to-voice-the-ogre|accessdate=17 July 2018}}</ref>
=== ''Indiana Jones and the Saucermen from Mars'' === In 1995, a time after the cancellation of ''[[The Young Indiana Jones Chronicles]]'', [[Jeb Stuart (writer)|Jeb Stuart]] wrote a script for the fourth film in the [[Indiana Jones (franchise)|''Indiana Jones'' film series,]] entitled ''Indiana Jones and the Saucermen from Mars''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mentalfloss.com/article/31320/lost-scripts-part-ii-indiana-jones-and-saucermen-mars|title=The Lost Scripts, Part II: Indiana Jones and the Saucermen from Mars|author=|date=27 July 2012|website=mentalfloss.com}}</ref> Spielberg was supposed to direct it, while [[George Lucas]] was supposed to serve as producer. Although Lucas loved the script, Spielberg and Ford had issues with it, so Spielberg hired ''[[Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade]]'' writer [[Jeffrey Boam]] to make a rewrite of Stuart's script. However, the script was finally rejected after the release of ''[[Independence Day (1996 film)|Independence Day]]'', which was released one year later. The fourth film, entitled ''[[Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull]]'', was finally released in 2008.
=== ''Meet the Parents'' === It was reported that back in 1996, Spielberg was slated to direct [[Jim Carrey]] in a remake of [[Greg Glienna]]'s 1992 film ''[[Meet the Parents (1992 film)|Meet the Parents]]'' for [[Universal Pictures]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Evans|first=Bradford|title=The Lost Roles of Jim Carrey|date=17 March 2011|publisher=[[Vulture.com]]|url=http://www.vulture.com/2011/03/the-lost-roles-of-jim-carrey.html|accessdate=17 July 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Cormier|first=Roger|title=15 Fun Facts About Meet the Parents|date=6 October 2015|publisher=''[[Mental Floss]]''|url=http://mentalfloss.com/article/69414/15-fun-facts-about-meet-parents|accessdate=17 July 2018}}</ref> However, Spielberg, along with Carrey, left the project due to schedule conflicts.<ref>{{cite web|title=Carrey Has 'No Regrets' Over Meet The Parents|date=16 December 2008|publisher=[[Contactmusic.com]]|url=http://www.contactmusic.com/jim-carrey/news/carrey-has-no-regrets-over-meet-the-parents_1089627|accessdate=17 July 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Carrey has 'no regrets' over 'Meet The Parents'|date=17 December 2008|publisher=''[[Irish Examiner]]''|url=https://www.irishexaminer.com/breakingnews/entertainment/carrey-has-no-regrets-over-meet-the-parents-390867.html|accessdate=17 July 2018}}</ref> Spielberg's company [[DreamWorks]] served as a co-distributor of the [[Meet the Parents|2000 remake]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Meet the Parents|date=14 November 2000|publisher=''[[Entertainment Weekly]]''|url=http://ew.com/article/2000/11/14/meet-parents-3/|accessdate=17 July 2018}}</ref>
=== ''The Truman Show'' === Spielberg was among the list of filmmakers considered to direct ''[[The Truman Show]]'' (1998) before [[Peter Weir]] officially assumed the position.<ref>{{cite web|last=Charisma|first=James|title=How The Truman Show Predicted the Future|date=4 June 2018|publisher=[[Yahoo!]]|url=https://www.yahoo.com/entertainment/truman-show-predicted-future-180106770.html|accessdate=10 October 2018}}</ref>
=== ''I'll Be Home'' === In 1999, Spielberg announced that he was working on an autobiographical film, entitled ''I'll Be Home'', but nothing came of this project.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fromdirectorstevenspielberg.tumblr.com/lost-spielberg|title=Lost and Unmade Spielberg|author=|date=|website=fromdirectorstevenspielberg.tumblr.com}}</ref>
== 2000s ==
=== ''The Curse of Monkey Island'' === In the start of 2000, Spielberg was set to make his first animated feature film based on the [[Lucasarts]] video game series ''[[Monkey Island (series)|Monkey Island]]'', a game series he was a fan of at the time. Spielberg was set to direct, produce and co-write the screenplay with [[Ted Elliott (screenwriter)|Ted Elliott]], with concept arts by the original game's designer [[Steve Purcell]] and animator [[Anthony Stacchi|Tony Stacchi]], executive produced by Steven's best friend and founder of the game's developer [[George Lucas]] (making the second collaboration between Spielberg and Lucas outside the [[Indiana Jones (franchise)|Indiana Jones]] series), co-production by [[Lucasfilm]] (Lucasarts' owner) and animation production by [[DreamWorks Animation]] and [[Industrial Light & Magic|ILM]]. Despite the concept arts being released, the film's production was shut down since George was busy making ''[[Star Wars: Episode II – Attack of the Clones]]'' and money problems. However some of the concepts later appeared in Ted's script to ''[[Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl]]'' that was made by [[DreamWorks]]' rival [[The Walt Disney Company|Disney]]. Later in 2011, Spielberg made his first animated film with [[Peter Jackson]] called ''[[The Adventures of Tintin (film)|The Adventures of Tintin]]''.
=== ''Indiana Jones and the City of Gods'' === On May 17, 2002, IGN reported that ''[[The Young Indiana Jones Chronicles]]'' writer [[Frank Darabont]] will write the fourth film of the film franchise of ''[[Indiana Jones (franchise)|Indiana Jones]]'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2002/05/17/ign-filmforce-exclusive-has-indy-iv-found-its-writer|title=IGN FilmForce Exclusive: Has Indy IV Found Its Writer?|first=Stax & Ken|last=Plume|date=17 May 2002|website=ign.com}}</ref> entitled ''Indiana Jones and the City of Gods'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/news/2008/02/spielberg_qanda200802|title=Q&A: Steven Spielberg on Indiana Jones|first=Jim|last=Windolf|date=|website=vanityfair.com}}</ref> in which ex-[[Nazis]] would chase Indiana Jones. The script is very similar to the final script, including Indy's and Marion's wedding and a scene with army ants, but it didn't include Indiana Jones' son. Spielberg liked the script very much, but [[George Lucas]] disliked it, and for that reason, he hired [[David Koepp]] to write the film. The film ended up being ''[[Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull]]'' which was released in 2008, with Spielberg returning as director.
=== ''The Catcher in the Rye'' === It was reported in 2003 that Spielberg attempted to direct a film adaptation of [[J.D. Salinger]]'s novel ''[[The Catcher in the Rye]]'' but could not obtain the rights from Salinger.<ref>{{cite web|title=Spielberg wanted to film Catcher In The Rye|date=5 December 2003|publisher=''[[Irish Examiner]]''|url=https://www.irishexaminer.com/breakingnews/entertainment/spielberg-wanted-to-film-catcher-in-the-rye-124346.html|accessdate=10 October 2018}}</ref>
=== ''The Goonies 2'' === On June 6, 2005, [[Richard Donner]] stated that he and Spielberg had written a story for a film sequel of Donner's acclaimed ''[[The Goonies]]'', despite the fact that the main cast did not have any interest in reprising their roles for a sequel.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aintitcool.com/node/20390|title=Chunk says Goonies Never Say Die, news on GOONIES 2!|first=|last=staff|date=|website=aintitcool.com}}</ref> However, in 2008, [[Corey Feldman]] stated on his personal blog that a sequel was unlikely to happen.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://coreyfeldman.wordpress.com/2008/11/25/goonies-2-lost-boys-3truth-movement-digital-release-today/|author=truecorylove|work=The Feldman Journal|date=November 25, 2008|title=GOONIES 2? LOST BOYS 3?…….TRUTH MOVEMENT DIGITAL RELEASE TODAY!!!!!}}</ref> Although on April 4, 2014, Donner confirmed that a sequel was in the works,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tmz.com/2014/04/05/richard-donner-goonies-sequel-finally-happening|title='Goonies' Sequel is Happening! -- Director Richard Donner's Bringing Everyone Back|author=|date=|website=tmz.com}}</ref> it's likely that Spielberg had abandoned the project.
=== ''OldBoy'' === Spielberg was attached to adapt the manga Oldboy in the late 2000's. Will Smith was set to star and it was reported to be based on the manga not the earlier film adaptation. The project was abandoned due to rights issues. <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2008-11-21/spielberg-smith-reportedly-adapting-old-boy-manga-itself|title=Spielberg and Smith Reportedly adapting OldBoy manga itself|website=animenewsnetwork}}</ref> The [[Oldboy (2013 film)|film]] ended up being released on November 27, 2013 directed by [[Spike Lee]] and starring [[Josh Brolin]]. <ref>{{cite web|last=Fleming|first=Mike|url=http://www.deadline.com/2011/08/josh-brolin-to-star-in-spike-lees-oldboy-redo-for-mandate/|title=Josh Brolin To Star In Spike Lee's 'Oldboy' Redo For Mandate|website=Deadline Hollywood|access-date=2012-10-14}}</ref>
=== ''Chocky'' === In September 2008, ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' reported that Spielberg had acquired the rights of [[John Wyndham]]'s novelette ''[[Chocky]]'' to make a film adaptation of it.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/|title=Hollywood Reporter - Entertainment News|author=|date=|work=The Hollywood Reporter}}</ref> However, no updates were made after this announcement.
=== ''Harvey'' === On August 2, 2009, Spielberg stated that he would direct a film adaptation of the play ''[[Harvey (play)|Harvey]]''. [[Will Smith]], [[Robert Downey, Jr.]] and [[Tom Hanks]] were considered to play the lead role, while [[Jonathan Tropper]] was hired to write the screenplay. [[DreamWorks]] and [[20th Century Fox]] would have developed the film.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2009/08/02/steven-spielbergs-next-film-will-be-harvey|title=Steven Spielberg's next film will be 'Harvey'|author=|date=|website=ew.com}}</ref> However, [[Collider (website)|Collider]] confirmed on December 4, 2009, that the project was cancelled due to problems with the lead role selection.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://collider.com/steven-spielbergs-harvey-remake-wont-become-a-reality/|title=Steven Spielberg's HARVEY Remake Won't Become a Reality|author=|date=3 December 2009|website=collider.com}}</ref>
==2010s==
=== ''Robopocalypse'' === On October 22, 2010, Spielberg had signed on to direct a film adaptation of ''[[Robopocalypse]]''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.deadline.com/2010/10/steven-spielberg-commits-to-direct-robopocalypse/|last=Fleming, Jr.|first=Mike|title=Steven Spielberg Commits To Next Direct 'Robopocalypse'|date=October 22, 2010|accessdate=January 17, 2017}}</ref> [[Chris Hemsworth]], [[Anne Hathaway]], and [[Ben Whishaw]] had signed on to star in the film.<ref name=Conceptart>{{cite news|last=Scieretta|first=Peter|url=http://www.slashfilm.com/robopocalypse-concept-art/|title=Concept Art: Steven Spielberg’s ‘Robopocalypse’|publisher=[[/Film]]|date=July 6, 2015|accessdate=January 17, 2017}}</ref> However, on January 9, 2013, ''Robopocalypse'' was placed on hold indefinitely mainly because of its production expenses.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/steven-spielbergs-robopocalypse-postponed-indefinitely-410519|title=Steven Spielberg's 'Robopocalypse' Postponed Indefinitely (Exclusive)|publisher=The Hollywood Reporter|accessdate=January 17, 2017|date=January 9, 2013|first=Kim|last=Masters}}</ref> The next day, Spielberg clarified he was working on a new script that would be "more economically but also much more ''personally''".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://insidemovies.ew.com/2013/01/10/robopocalypse-steven-spielberg-still-on/|title='Robopocalypse' delay: Steven Spielberg vows it's not dead!|publisher=Entertainment Weekly|date=January 10, 2013|accessdate=January 7, 2017|first=Anthony|last=Breznican}}</ref> In July 2015, concept artwork was leaked onto the Internet.<ref name=Conceptart /> On March 7, 2018, [[Michael Bay]] signed on to direct the adaptation.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://variety.com/2018/film/news/michael-bay-new-movies-six-underground-robopocalypse-1202721030/|last=Kroll|first=Justin|title=Michael Bay Sets ‘6 Underground,’ 'Robopocalypse' as Next Two Films (EXCLUSIVE)|date=7 March 2018|website=Variety|accessdate=13 April 2018}}</ref>
